items.title: Riot raises $30 million for its cybersecurity product suite focused on employees
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- French startup [Riot](https://tryriot.com/) raised $30 million in Series B funding after achieving $10 million in annual revenue in 2024.
- Led by Left Lane Capital, with participation from Y Combinator, Base10, and FundersClub, Riot's post-money valuation is over $170 million.
- Riot plans to expand its focus from educating employees on phishing to managing employee security posture with a new platform, aiming to prevent cyber incidents that are on the rise.

items.title: Samsung chief Jay Y. Lee cleared of all charges in 2015 merger case
items.author: Kate Park
items.summary:
- A Seoul appeals court upheld the acquittal of Jay Y. Lee, Samsung's Executive Chairman, in a 2015 merger case.
- Lee faced 19 charges related to accounting fraud and stock manipulation but was found not guilty.
- The court dismissed the prosecution's appeal, stating that the merger followed standard operational procedures between Samsung affiliates.

items.title: Tana snaps up $25M, with its AI-powered knowledge graph for work racking up a 160k+ waitlist
items.summary:
- Tana has emerged from stealth with $25 million in funding.
- It features AI-powered tools for automated task management, note-taking, and action item generation.
- Tana has already built a waitlist of over 160,000 users and tested by 30,000 in a closed beta.
- The platform is designed for individuals and teams to improve efficiency through a 'knowledge graph.'
- The application can listen to conversations and transcribe them into actionable data.
- Founded by ex-Googlers, Tana's development focuses on leveraging AI models, partnering primarily with OpenAI.

items.title: DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng receives a hero’s welcome back home
items.summary:
- DeepSeek founder Liang Wenfeng returns to Guangdong, China, for the Lunar New Year, celebrated with a hero's welcome.
- Wenfeng is a billionaire hedge fund manager known for his research showing AI models can be built with fewer Nvidia chips, crucial for China.
- Locals describe him as a top student from an educational family, and there's a sense of pride in his achievements, despite his desire to avoid public attention.

items.title: India expands Aadhaar authentication for businesses, raising privacy concerns
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- India has eased restrictions on its Aadhaar authentication service for businesses across various sectors.  
- The Indian IT ministry introduced new rules allowing wider use of Aadhaar for service delivery as of February 2, 2025.  
- These changes have raised privacy concerns, especially regarding the safeguarding of biometric data and the potential for misuse.  
- The amendment comes two years after public consultation, with responses undisclosed.  
- The amendment broadens authentication services, previously limited mostly to banking and telecom industries.  
- In January, Aadhaar authentication transactions reached 129.93 billion, an increase from the previous year.  
- New applications for Aadhaar authentication will need approval from the Indian government based on UIDAI's recommendations.  
- Experts are calling for clearer guidelines to prevent misuse and ensure transparency in the application process.

items.title: OpenAI unveils a new ChatGPT agent for ‘deep research’
items.summary:
- OpenAI announced a new AI agent for in-depth research, named ChatGPT deep research.
- Designed for professionals in finance, science, policy, and engineering needing detailed and reliable research.
- Available for ChatGPT Pro users with a limit of 100 queries per month; wider rollout plans include Plus and Team users.
- Integration with mobile and desktop apps is expected later this month.
- Outputs will be text only initially, with future plans for images and data visualizations.
- ChatGPT deep research ensures documentation and citations for its outputs to enhance credibility.
- The new o3 model powering this feature has been trained for better reasoning and data analysis.
- Initial test results showed 26.6% accuracy on a challenging expert-level exam, outperforming its competitors.

items.title: Dub: the copy trading app that has teens talking
items.author: Steven Wang
items.summary:
- Dub is a copy trading app that allows users to mimic the trades of top investors.
- The app was founded by 23-year-old Steven Wang and has gained over 800,000 downloads and raised $17 million in seed funding.
- Dub operates on a subscription model, charging $10 per month, and takes a 25% cut of management fees from top portfolios.
- Wang emphasizes user education, providing risk scores and portfolio metrics to help informed decision-making.
- Critics argue that active stock picking underperforms passive investing; however, Wang contests these claims, citing the success of hedge funds.

items.title: Apple reportedly launching a new event invite feature code-named Confetti
items.summary:
- Apple is set to introduce a new event invite feature for iCloud users, code-named Confetti.
- The feature will allow users to invite others to parties, meetings, and events.
- Confetti might launch as soon as this week and could be part of a broader revamp of Apple’s Calendar app.
- The release is associated with iOS 18.3, which has started rolling out recently.

items.title: Google’s X spins out Heritable Agriculture, a startup using AI to improve crop yield
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Google X has spun out a new startup, [Heritable Agriculture](https://heritable.ag/), focused on using AI to enhance crop yield.
- The startup aims to address environmental challenges in agriculture, which accounts for about 25% of greenhouse gas emissions.
- Founder Brad Zamft, a PhD in physics, developed the technology at Google X, analyzing plant genomes for better agricultural practices.
- Heritable Agriculture is not using genetic modification or gene editing but is focused on traditional breeding methods to optimize plant growth.

items.title: AI systems with ‘unacceptable risk’ are now banned in the EU
items.summary:
- As of February 2, 2025, the EU can ban AI systems posing 'unacceptable risk'.
- This is the first compliance deadline following the EU’s AI Act, which went into force on August 1, 2024.
- AI systems categorized as high risk will face heavy oversight; those deemed unacceptable are prohibited entirely, including social scoring and manipulation of decisions.
- Companies using prohibited AI applications may face fines up to €35 million or 7% of their annual revenue.
- Organizations are expected to fully comply by February 2, with additional enforcement details coming in August 2025.

items.title: Shein app returns to India via Reliance deal
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- Shein has relaunched in India through a partnership with Reliance Retail after nearly five years of being banned.
- The new Shein India Fast Fashion app gives Reliance complete control over operations and data.
- All customer data must be stored in India, with Shein having no access rights.
- Initial delivery is offered in cities like New Delhi, Bengaluru, and Mumbai, with plans for nationwide expansion.
- The partnership aims to enhance India's textile manufacturing sector while ensuring data sovereignty.

items.title: Senator warns of national security risks after Elon Musk’s DOGE granted ‘full access’ to sensitive Treasury systems
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- Sen. Ron Wyden warns that Elon Musk’s DOGE team received ‘full access’ to a U.S. Treasury payments system, posing a national security risk.
- The authorization was given by Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent, following a previous standoff regarding access.
- This system disburses around $6 trillion annually, covering Social Security, Medicare, and contractor payments, and is historically limited to a few staff members.
- Wyden expresses concerns over Musk’s business interests in China, citing potential conflicts of interest and cybersecurity risks.
- Multiple federal departments, including the Office of Personnel Management, are also under scrutiny by DOGE.

items.title: X expands lawsuit over advertiser ‘boycott’ to include Lego, Nestlé, Pinterest, and others
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- X, formerly Twitter, expands its antitrust lawsuit claiming a systematic illegal boycott by advertisers.
- The lawsuit was initially filed in August 2024 against the World Federation of Advertisers and its Global Alliance of Responsible Media initiative.
- The complaint now includes companies like Nestlé, Lego, and Pinterest, alleging coordinated efforts to harm X's advertising revenue.
- At least 18 GARM-affiliated advertisers reportedly stopped advertising on X between November and December 2022.
- X claims reduced ad spending and lower prices due to the boycott, harming its revenue from small and medium-sized businesses.

items.title: Adobe exec Scott Belsky departs for indie movie studio A24
items.summary:
- Adobe’s chief strategy officer Scott Belsky is joining independent movie studio A24.
- He has been with Adobe since 2012, initially through the acquisition of Behance.
- A24 is known for critically acclaimed films and has won Oscars for "Everything Everywhere All At Once" and "Moonlight."
- Belsky mentioned he will be working on special projects at A24, aiming to support the studio's storytelling efforts.

items.title: DeepSeek gets Silicon Valley talking
items.author: Cody Corrall
items.summary:
- DeepSeek went viral due to its AI models sparking discussions about the U.S. maintaining its lead in AI and the sustainability of AI chip demand.
- DeepSeek claims its R1 reasoning model performs on par with OpenAI’s o1 model on key benchmarks.
- American teens have expressed low trust in Big Tech, with a majority believing companies do not prioritize their well-being or ethical decisions regarding AI.

items.title: Here are all the IPOs reported to be in the works for 2025
items.author: Charles Rollet
items.summary:
- Tech companies are optimistic about going public in 2025 due to a new presidential administration easing regulations.
- Notable companies filing for IPOs include eToro, Voyager Technologies, and Karman Holdings, all filed in January 2025.
- Several companies are looking to go public after prior confidential filings, including Chime, Klarna, and Genesys, with potential IPOs planned in 2025.
- The fast-fashion giant Shein and growth equity investor General Atlantic are continuing their IPO pursuits after previous attempts over the last two years.

items.title: Here are the apps battling to be become the ‘TikTok for Bluesky’
items.summary:
- TikTok’s potential U.S. ban has led to increased development of apps that could replace it for users of the decentralized social network Bluesky.
- Several apps focusing on video content for Bluesky are in development, including Bluescreen, Reelo, Skylight, and Videos for Bluesky.
- Reelo is creating a standalone app on the AT Protocol, offering features like longer videos and livestreaming, expecting to launch by March 20, 2025.
- Skylight is also in beta and aims to provide a TikTok-like experience but is limited by Bluesky's video restrictions.
- The recently launched Videos for Bluesky allows for vertical video browsing and offers user features like trending videos and custom feeds.
- Flipboard's Surf app incorporates a video feed and aims to personalize offerings for users across the open social web.
- BlueSky Reels focuses on creating curated video feeds and may offer moderation similar to Reddit.

items.title: Venture debt lenders will play a big role in fire sales and startup shutdown this year, experts say
items.author: Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- The accounting startup Bench failed after lenders called in the loan, leaving many businesses without accounting access.
- Venture lending firm Hercules Capital took control of digital freight company Convoy due to financial challenges.
- Venture debt reached a record $53.3 billion in 2024, with major funding for AI companies like CoreWeave and OpenAI.
- Experts predict many startups will be forced into fire sales or shutdowns in 2025 as lenders push for acquisitions to minimize losses.
- The risks associated with venture debt are significant, especially for underperforming startups potentially facing foreclosure or forced sales.

items.title: How to delete X and move on with your life
items.summary:
- X, formerly known as Twitter, has seen a decline in daily active users prompting some to leave the platform entirely.
- Users are exploring alternatives like [Bluesky](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/16/what-is-bluesky-everything-to-know-about-the-x-competitor/), [Mastodon](https://techcrunch.com/2023/07/24/what-is-mastodon/), and [Threads](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/16/what-is-instagrams-threads-app-all-your-questions-answered/).
- To delete your account, users can first download their data and then deactivate their accounts with a 30-day grace period before permanent deletion.

items.title: AI agents could birth the first one-person unicorn — but at what societal cost?
India pledges fresh billion for startups
items.author: Manish Singh
items.summary:
- India announced a new $1.15 billion Fund of Funds for startups, aiming to boost tech innovation and clean energy.
- The fund builds on previous programs that deployed over $1 billion, with expanded scope but no specific focuses detailed.
- A High-Level Committee for Regulatory Reforms will review all non-financial sector regulations within a year.
- New Deep Tech Fund of Funds to support startups in advanced technologies as part of a broader tech sector push.
- India’s startup ecosystem has attracted over $100 billion from investors, contributing significantly to job creation.
- A $2.3 billion Nuclear Energy Mission aims to develop five indigenous small modular reactors by 2033.
- Startups can now claim tax benefits until 2030 and access increased credit guarantees of $230,000.
- A new scheme for 500,000 first-time entrepreneurs will provide loans of up to $24,000 over five years.

items.title: Autonomous vehicle testing in California dropped 50%. Here’s why.
items.author: Kirsten Korosec
items.summary:
- Testing of autonomous vehicles in California fell 50% in 2024, logging 4.5 million miles.
- Driverless testing saw an 83% decline, dropping to 552,895 miles.
- The decline reflects few active companies; Waymo and Cruise were significant players, with Cruise halting tests entirely.
- As of 2024, only 31 companies hold safety driver permits, with just 11 conducting tests.
- The DMV issued only one new permit in 2024, down from four in 2022 and two in 2023.
- The industry has consolidated, with fewer companies willing to invest heavily in autonomous vehicle development.

items.title: OpenAI used this subreddit to test AI persuasion
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- OpenAI utilized [r/ChangeMyView](https://www.reddit.com/r/changemyview/) for testing AI's persuasive abilities with its new reasoning model, [o3-mini](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/31/openai-launches-o3-mini-its-latest-reasoning-model/).
- The subreddit features posts from users seeking diverse viewpoints, receiving persuasive replies from others.
- OpenAI collects content from this subreddit to create tests and evaluates the AI's responses compared to human arguments, but no public release of this evaluation is planned.
- OpenAI also has a licensing deal with Reddit for utilizing user posts in its products, though the ChangeMyView evaluation is reportedly separate from this agreement.
- The o3-mini model performs similarly to previous models but is noted as competitive in persuasive argumentation, virtually on par with humans.

items.title: Sam Altman: OpenAI has been on the ‘wrong side of history’ concerning open source
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Sam Altman stated OpenAI has been 'on the wrong side of history' regarding open-source technologies.
- OpenAI is facing competition from companies like DeepSeek, leading to a reevaluation of its open-sourcing strategies.
- Altman mentioned potential plans to open-source older models and enhance the transparency of reasoning models.
- The company is engaged in significant financing efforts, with ongoing relationships with government bodies for nuclear defense research.
- Altman indicated a shift in OpenAI's approach to model development and a potential future release strategy.

items.title: Mistral board member and a16z VC Anjney Midha says DeepSeek won’t stop AI’s GPU hunger
items.author: Anjney Midha
items.summary:
• Anjney Midha, a16z VC and Mistral board member, discusses DeepSeek's performance compared to GPT4-Turbo.
• DeepSeek's latest model, R1, challenges the AI industry by providing high efficiency at lower costs amid GPU demand.
• Despite improvements, Midha asserts foundational AI models will still require vast GPU resources and more data centers.
• Mistral remains competitive due to its open-source approach, allowing access to free technical support.
• The Oxygen GPU sharing program is currently overbooked, highlighting the intense demand for GPUs in AI development.
• Companies are recognizing the strategic importance of AI infrastructure similar to electricity and the internet, advocating for Western models over Chinese ones.

items.title: MLCommons and Hugging Face team up to release massive speech data set for AI research
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- MLCommons and Hugging Face released the 'Unsupervised People’s Speech' dataset with over 1 million hours of audio in 89 languages.
- The initiative aims to advance research in speech technology and improve communication technologies globally.
- The dataset may have biases and potential privacy issues, as most recordings are in American-accented English and some contributors might not have consented for their voices to be used.

items.title: Hundreds of companies are blocking DeepSeek over China data risks
items.summary:
- DeepSeek, a Chinese chatbot, gained popularity in the U.S., topping app store charts.
- Hundreds of companies, particularly with government ties, have blocked the service over data security concerns, citing potential data leakage to the Chinese government.
- The Pentagon and the Navy have implemented restrictions against DeepSeek due to its data policies which require sharing user data with Chinese authorities upon request.

items.title: Elon Musk is reportedly taking control of the inner workings of US government agencies
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Elon Musk's associates are allegedly taking over key operations in multiple government agencies, including the Office of Personnel Management and the Treasury Department.
- The highest-ranking official at the Treasury is leaving after a conflict with Musk's team regarding access to sensitive federal payment systems, which manage over $6 trillion annually.
- Musk's team is reportedly locking out career civil servants from computer systems containing personal data of millions of federal employees.
- Tech workers in the government are facing scrutiny from Musk's aides, leading to code reviews and a government-wide email encouraging employee resignations.
- Musk's takeover mirrors the disorganized period after his acquisition of Twitter, representing an unprecedented influence over the U.S. government.

items.title: Guo’s Conviction Partners adds Mike Vernal as GP, raises $230M fund
items.author: Sarah Guo, Mike Vernal
items.summary:
- Sarah Guo, founder of Conviction Partners, adds Mike Vernal as General Partner.
- Conviction Partners closed a $230 million second fund, more than double the $101 million first fund.
- Guo has established a strong presence in the AI investment sector in Silicon Valley.
- Vernal previously worked at Sequoia and led numerous successful investments.

items.title: Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei is trying to duck a deposition in an OpenAI copyright lawsuit
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei is attempting to avoid a deposition in a copyright lawsuit against OpenAI.
- The Authors Guild has filed a motion to compel testimony from Amodei and his co-founder Benjamin Mann, citing their unique knowledge relevant to the case.
- The lawsuit, representing writers like John Grisham and George R.R. Martin, was filed in September 2023 in the U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York.
- Amodei and Mann agreed to seven-hour depositions originally but have since delayed them, hoping to align with another lawsuit's testimony schedule.
- Their lawyers claim Amodei is unavailable for deposition due to a demanding schedule.
- Mann has requested that his deposition be coordinated with other lawsuits and has cited personal reasons for wanting to limit its duration and conditions.

items.title: CFPB fines fintech Wise, alleging it charged deceptive fees
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo
items.summary:
- The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau (CFPB) fined Wise about $2 million for deceptive practices.
- CFPB alleges Wise misled consumers about ATM fees and failed to disclose other costs.
- Customers were harmed when remittance fees were not refunded in a timely manner.
- Wise has agreed to pay $450,000 in redress to consumers and a civil monetary penalty.
- Wise claims to have cooperated with the CFPB and addressed identified issues promptly.
- This fine follows increased scrutiny on fintech companies regarding compliance and honesty in their practices.

items.title: Apple will pay $20M to settle Watch battery swelling suit, ‘denies wrongdoing’
items.author: Brian Heater
items.summary:
- Apple will pay $20 million to settle a class-action lawsuit over battery swelling in the Apple Watch, affecting the first four models.
- The lawsuit was filed in 2019 in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California.
- Apple denies wrongdoing and claims the settlement is not an admission of guilt. 
- Users must have reported the issue between April 24, 2015, and February 6, 2024, to qualify for compensation ranging from $20 to $50.
- Claimants need to submit information to the lawsuit’s official site before April 10, 2025.

items.title: Meta turns to solar — again — in its data center-building boom
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
[Meta signed a deal with Zelestra for 595 megawatts of solar power in Texas, increasing its renewable capacity by nearly 5%.]
[The company plans to invest $60 billion in 2025, mainly for data center infrastructure as part of its AI strategy.]
[Meta and competitors anticipate nuclear power will provide additional capacity in the future, but are relying on faster renewable energy deployment for immediate needs.]

items.title: Stablecoins are finding product market fit in emerging markets
items.summary:
- SpaceX uses stablecoins for payments in developing markets due to unreliable banking infrastructure.
- Partnered with Bridge for accepting and converting payments into stablecoins.
- Stablecoins remove friction in cross-border transactions, driving a $205 billion market.
- Startups like Yellow Card and Conduit see massive transaction volume growth in stablecoin solutions.
- Brazilian unicorn Nubank rewards USDC holders with a 4% annual return, indicating stablecoin growth in consumer finance.
- Startups like Rise and Cashnote.io test stablecoin applications for payroll and retail payments.
- Regulatory environments like Abu Dhabi support fintech innovation, impacting stablecoin adoption positively.
- Concerns exist about regulation and monetary policy disruption as stablecoins become more common.

items.title: This investor wants you to sign an NDA to build Legos together
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Investor Nat Friedman posted an offer on X for volunteers to help construct a 5000 piece Lego set in his Palo Alto office.
- Participants must sign a Non-Disclosure Agreement (NDA) and will be provided with pizza.
- The unusual request has sparked curiosity about the secrets potentially related to the Lego event and Friedman's motives.

items.title: Sam Altman’s ousting from OpenAI has entered the cultural zeitgeist
items.summary:
- The play "Doomers" premiered in New York City, inspired by Sam Altman’s ousting as CEO of OpenAI in November 2023.
- It explores themes of AI safety and the philosophical implications of rapid technological advancement through fictionalized events.
- Sam Altman is depicted as the character Seth, who argues against slowing down AI development, suggesting it is crucial to pursue excellence and innovation.
- The play highlights ongoing debates on AI’s existential risks versus its promises, aligning with current global discussions on technology's impact.
- After Altman's firing, he was reinstated when OpenAI engineers threatened to resign, leading to a new board aligned with his vision.

items.title: OpenAI launches o3-mini, its latest ‘reasoning’ model
items.summary:
- OpenAI launched a new AI reasoning model, o3-mini, expanding its o family of reasoning models.
- The model aims to provide powerful and affordable AI, marking a step toward broader accessibility.
- O3-mini is fine-tuned for STEM problems, running faster and at a lower cost compared to o1-family models.
- It offers a range of reasoning effort levels for developers and has cheaper pricing than competitors like DeepSeek.
- Available starting Friday via ChatGPT for premium users, and to select developers through OpenAI's API.
- O3-mini's performance is assessed against competition, with claims of higher reliability in certain technical domains.

items.title: Swiss tax authority forced to buy Bahamas domain name after URL typo
items.summary:
- The Swiss canton of Basel-Stadt bought a domain after a typo on 100,000 printed flyers.
- The flyers omitted the Swiss domain suffix '.ch', using '.bs', which belongs to the Bahamas.
- Instead of reprinting the flyers for $100,000, the canton opted to spend $1,000 on the new domain to redirect correctly.
- The new URL is not live yet; registration is still in process.

items.title: Microsoft is forming a new unit to study AI’s impacts
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Microsoft has established the Advanced Planning Unit (APU) to analyze the societal, health, and work implications of AI.
- The APU will report to CEO Mustafa Suleyman and focus on research, product recommendations, and publications regarding AI's future.
- Current hiring includes economists and psychologists to explore the implications of AI advancements.
- The formation of APU follows a recent creation of a new internal dev-focused organization, CoreAI, to prioritize AI development within Microsoft.
- Microsoft's capital expenditures for Q4 2024 reached a record high of $22.6 billion to support AI efforts, as stated by CEO Satya Nadella.

items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- DeepSeek's chatbot app has gone viral, reaching the top of both the [Apple App Store](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/27/deepseek-displaces-chatgpt-as-the-app-stores-top-app/) and [Google Play Store](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/28/deepseek-reaches-no-1-on-us-play-store/).
- DeepSeek is funded by [High-Flyer Capital Management](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/28/who-is-liang-wenfeng-deepseek-founder-comes-from-ai-investing/), a Chinese hedge fund focused on AI.
- The company’s first models were released in November 2023, with the [DeepSeek-V2](https://techcrunch.com/2024/12/26/deepseeks-new-ai-model-appears-to-be-one-of-the-best-open-challengers-yet/) family debuting in Spring 2024, gaining industry attention for its efficiency.
- DeepSeek’s [R1 reasoning model](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/27/deepseek-claims-its-reasoning-model-beats-openais-o1-on-certain-benchmarks/) was noted for performing well against OpenAI's offerings.
- The company’s models are subject to [regulatory benchmarks](https://www.ft.com/content/10975044-f194-4513-857b-e17491d2a9e9) to ensure compliance with socialist values in China.
- Microsoft announced integration of DeepSeek models into its [Azure AI Foundry service](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/29/microsoft-brings-a-deepseek-model-to-its-cloud/), adding to its growing influence.
- Market reaction included a 18% drop in [Nvidia's stock price](https://techcrunch.com/2025/01/27/nvidia-drops-600bn-off-its-market-cap-amid-the-rise-of-deepseek/) following DeepSeek's ascent.

items.title: Custom feed builder Graze is building a business on Bluesky, and investors are paying attention
items.author: null
items.summary:
- Graze is a startup that enables users to build custom feeds for the Bluesky social network and is attracting investor interest.
- The platform will soon allow content creators to monetize their feeds through advertising, sponsored posts, and subscriptions.
- Graze is experiencing rapid growth, serving hundreds of thousands of unique users daily and gaining millions of content impressions through word of mouth.
- Founders Peat Bakke and Devin Gaffney previously collaborated on social data analysis startup Little Bird.
- Graze leverages Bluesky’s Jetstream, allowing users to create complex feeds using custom algorithms.
- The startup has witnessed growth linked to Bluesky's rising popularity, gaining 23 million users over the past year.
- Graze maintains a unique approach to monetization, respecting Bluesky’s privacy while offering ads integrated into custom feeds with editorial control for users.
- Plans for future tools include private feeds requiring subscription payments and a revenue split model similar to app stores.

items.title: WeDoSolar pivots to B2B, after stake acquired by Chinese solar giant
items.author: Mike Butcher
items.summary:
- WeDoSolar pivots from B2C to B2B after acquiring minority stake by Genbyte Tech.
- Genbyte Tech, a Chinese solar giant, will provide technical expertise and infrastructure for scaling operations.
- CEO and Co-Founder Karolina Attspodina steps down but will remain involved as a shareholder and board member. Qian Qin takes over as CEO.
- WeDoSolar aims to cater to resellers, property developers, and commercial enterprises in the solar market.

items.title: AI startup Perplexity sued for alleged trademark infringement
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Perplexity is being sued in federal court for trademark infringement by Perplexity Solved Solutions.
- The complaint alleges that Perplexity began infringing on trademarks in August 2022 and did not comply with a cease and desist letter.
- Perplexity Solved Solutions is seeking legal relief, including a ban on the use of the trademark and damages.

items.title: A brief history of mass-hacks
items.summary:
- Enterprise cybersecurity tools are designed to protect corporate networks but often contain vulnerabilities that hackers exploit.
- The Clop ransomware gang has been involved in multiple mass-hacking incidents, exploiting various vulnerabilities across different organizations.
- Significant mass-hacks include the MOVEit breach affecting 60 million people's data, and a recent string of exploits affecting companies like Citrix and Ivanti.
- Ongoing concerns about cybersecurity vulnerabilities continue to challenge enterprises and raise the risk of mass-hacking campaigns.

items.title: Backed by Mayo Clinic, Nutrix’s hardware monitors worker stress
items.author: Anna Heim
items.summary:
- Workplace stress costs U.S. businesses over $300 billion annually, impacting absenteeism and productivity.
- Nutrix’s CortiSense device measures cortisol levels in saliva, recently awarded CES Innovation Award 2025 in Digital Health.
- Supported by Mayo Clinic and a $4 million funding, Nutrix plans to use CortiSense for corporate health monitoring as it expands into the U.S.

items.title: Tata Technologies says ransomware attack hit IT assets, investigation ongoing
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- Tata Technologies experienced a ransomware attack affecting some IT assets, requiring service suspension.
- Client delivery services remained fully functional and unaffected.
- An investigation is being conducted to determine the root cause and necessary remedial actions.
- Specific details about the ransomware group and ransom demands were not disclosed.
- Tata Technologies was founded in 1989 and operates in 27 countries with over 12,500 employees, having acquired several global engineering entities before a planned IPO in November 2023.

items.title: WhatsApp disrupts hacking campaign targeting journalists with Paragon spyware
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- WhatsApp disrupted a hacking campaign targeting around 90 users, including journalists and civil society members.
- The campaign was linked to Paragon, an Israeli spyware company acquired in December by AE Industrial.
- Malicious PDFs sent via WhatsApp groups were used to compromise victims, and WhatsApp implemented a fix to prevent this.
- The hacking campaign is believed to have occurred in December, with a cease and desist letter sent to Paragon.
- This marks Paragon's first public link to a hacking campaign targeting journalists.
- WhatsApp's actions have been praised by digital rights advocates for holding spyware companies accountable.

items.title: TechCrunch Disrupt 2025: Last 24 hours for 2-for-1 Pass
items.summary:
- Final opportunity for 2-for-1 Passes for TechCrunch Disrupt 2025 until tonight at 11:59 p.m. PT.
- Event scheduled for October 27-29, 2025 in San Francisco at Moscone West.
- Features AI topics, expert discussions, startup pitch competitions, and networking opportunities.
- Unique opportunity to purchase one pass at a discounted rate and receive a second pass for nearly free.
- Last chance to secure tickets at the lowest rates before the offer ends.

items.title: The TechCrunch Cyber Glossary
items.summary:
- A comprehensive glossary of cybersecurity terms created by TechCrunch.
- Includes common and less common jargon used in cybersecurity articles.
- The glossary will be regularly updated and invites user feedback.
- Key entries include definitions for terms like Advanced Persistent Threat, Backdoor, and DDoS.
- Addresses the significance of proper terminology in understanding cybersecurity incidents.

items.title: US nonprofit healthcare provider says hackers stole medical and personal data of 1M+ patients
items.summary:
- Community Health Center (CHC), a nonprofit healthcare provider in Connecticut, reported that hackers stole sensitive data of over a million patients.
- The breach was detected on January 2, 2025, with unauthorized access starting on October 14, 2024.
- The hacked data may include personal identifiers like addresses, phone numbers, Social Security numbers, and health information.
